CATARACT.title: Anterior polar cataract
CATARACT.description: Anterior polar cataracts are congenital opacities involving the anterior capsule and subcapsular cortex. They are typically small, bilateral, symmetric, non-progressive, and not visually significant. The patient in these photographs had anterior polar cataracts that were more prominent in the left eye than the right. Only the left cataract was visually significant. OD - Slit Lamp

images.alt: Anterior Polar Catatact Slit Lamp OD
Anterior Polar Catatact Slit Lamp OS

CATARACT.title: Anterior subcapsular cataract
CATARACT.description: Anterior subcapsular cataracts (ASC) form after anterior lens epithelial cells become necrotic from a variety of causes including iritis, keratitis, inflammation associated with atopic dermatitis, irradiation, or electrical burns. The opacification of the lens is due to a migration of adjacent epithelial cells into the damaged area and subsequent transformation of these cells into a plaque of multiple layers of myofibroblasts. The most posterior layer of these cells remain epithelial cells and will produce a new lens capsule. Over time the myofibroblasts resolve leaving a wrinkled appearance to the lens capsule. A duplication cataract occurs when a cortical cataract develops in the same area as the ASC.

CATARACT.title: Anterior capsular phimosis
CATARACT.photographer: Stefani Karakas, CRA; D. Brice Critser, CRA; Antoinette Venckus, CRA
CATARACT.description: Anterior capsular phimosis is the centripetal fibrosis and contraction of the capsulorhexis after cataract extraction. Individuals with zonular laxity are at increased risk for this condition. Mild to moderate amounts of phimosis are usually not visually significant, but severe cases may require treatment by Nd:YAG laser anterior capsulotomy. Figure1. Non-visually-significant anterior capsular phimosis after cataract surgery.Photographer: Stefani Karakas, CRA

CATARACT.description: Stellate, anterior subcapsular cataract with granular, brown deposits along the suture lines in a patient taking chlorpromazine.

CATARACT.title: Combined Anterior Polar, Posterior Subcapsular and Cortical Cataract
CATARACT.description: This is a 40-year-old male referred for cataract evaluation. He complained of blurred vision and photosensitivity. His visual acuity is 20/400 in this eye. On exam he had a unilateral anterior polar cataract combined with central posterior subcapsular cataract with mild cortical changes. He elected to proceed with cataract extraction.

CATARACT.title: Congenital nuclear cataract
CATARACT.description: Congenital nuclear cataracts may involve the entire nucleus, or a portion of it as seen in this photograph. These photographs also show a mild persistent pupillary membrane which is most visible in the red reflex.

CATARACT.title: Glaukomflecken and iris atrophy after acute angle closure glaucoma
CATARACT.description: Glaukomflecken are small anterior subcapsular opacities secondary to lens epithelial necrosis resulting from acute angle closure glaucoma. These photographs from two different patients show central glaukomflecken and iris atrophy secondary to prior episodes of acute angle closure glaucoma..

CATARACT.title: Iris incarceration in an old extracapsular wound
CATARACT.description: This 73-year-old male had a complicated extracapsular cataract extraction 40 years ago for bilateral cataracts and was left aphakic. There is uveal tissue incarcerated in the old superior wound. This makes secondary intraocular lens placement difficult and potentially high risk.

CATARACT.title: Morgagnian cataract
CATARACT.description: Morgagnian cataracts are advanced cortical cataracts in which the nucleus is freely mobile within liquefied cortex. In this photo, a brunescent nucleus can be seen sunken to the bottom of the capsular bag with the white, liquefied cortex visible superiorly.

CATARACT.description: The patient was a 57-year-old man with vision loss in the right eye (OD) greater than left eye (OS) in the setting of a craniopharyngioma, which was resected 16 years prior. His visual acuity had been no light perception OD and 20/20 OS since the procedure.

CATARACT.title: Persistent fetal vasculature (PFV)
CATARACT.description: Persistent fetal vasculature (PFV), previously called persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous (PHPV), is a congenital defect that results when the fetal hyaloid vasculature fails to regress. The condition is almost always unilateral and associated with microphthalmia. Variable degrees of vascular remnants may remain, ranging from an isolated retrolenticular membrane to a complete stalk connecting the optic nerve to the lens as in this case. Other associated findings can include enlongated ciliary processes, prominent radial vessels or neovascularization on the iris surface, shallow anterior chamber with narrow-angle glaucoma, vitreous hemorrhage, and retinal detachment. In this photograph, a stalk can be seen emanating from the optic disc into the vitreous with tenting of the surrounding retina and dragging of the macula. The associated cataract has been removed surgically

images.alt: a stalk can be seen emanating from the optic disc into the vitreous with tenting of the surrounding retina and dragging of the macula

CATARACT.title: Posterior Polar Cataract
CATARACT.description: Posterior polar cataracts are a form of congenital cataract commonly associated with posterior capsule changes. They can be autosomal dominant or sporadic and are more commonly bilateral. They are rarely visually significant and are usually stable, but may progress over time. This 42-year-old patient was referred from an outside provider with complaints of blurred vision at distance and near in addition to being bothered by glare. He had 2.5 mm concentric posterior polar opacities in both eyes and elected to undergo cataract extraction

CATARACT.description: Pseudophakic late in-the-bag lens dislocation in a patient with pseudoexfoliation glaucoma. In this particular case, refixation or lens exchange is more complicated and challenging in the setting of trabeculectomy bleb is shown.

CATARACT.title: Aftercataract (Elschnig's pearls)
CATARACT.description: September 18, 2023 Our patient is a 47-year-old male with a history of myotonic muscular dystrophy and bilateral cataract extraction with implantation of intraocular lens. This was complicated by the development of bilateral dense posterior capsular opacities that were resistant to YAG capsulotomy (attempted twice in the right eye prior to this presentation). He presented with 2 days of “a line in my vision that changes angles when I move my head.” During the slit lamp exam, he was noted to have a large Elschnig pearl suspended in his central visual axis which swung with his eye movements as demonstrated in the video above. Hanging Elschnig Pearl

CATARACT.title: Phacomorphic Angle Closure and Anterior Lens Dislocation due to Repeated Blunt Trauma
CATARACT.contributor: Lauren E. Hock, MD and A. Tim Johnson, MD, PhD
CATARACT.description: Lensectomy is the definitive treatment for both phacomorphic angle closure and pupillary block secondary to lens dislocation. Slit lamp photograph of the right eye shows 3+ diffuse injection with the crystalline lens filling the anterior chamber, lenticulocorneal touch, stromal edema, 360 degree iridocorneal touch, and posterior capsule opacification. Intraocular pressure was 40 mmHg at presentation.

This image, taken one month after the procedure, shows prominent capsular phimosis with radial folds and central 2-3+ capsular opacification. This was treated using a Nd:YAG laser posterior capsulotomy. Coppock Cataract
CATARACT.description: This is called a "Coppock cataract," also known as a "central pulverulent cataract." It refers to a pulverulent disc-like opactiy involving the embryonal and fetal nucleus with many tiny white dots in the lamellar portion of the lens. It is usually bilateral and dominantly inherited.

Hyphema following aborted iStent procedure
CATARACT.contributor: Austin R. Fox, MD, and Michael Griess, MD
CATARACT.description: External photograph of the left eye shows a contracting post-operative hyphema two weeks after an iStent® trabecular micro-bypass procedure. The surgery had been aborted due to development of a hyphema and poor view. A hyphema is a rare complication during iStent insertion but has been reported in several publications [1-7]. However, microhyphemas observed on gonioscopy after the iStent procedure are more commonly seen.

CATARACT.title: Iridodialysis and traumatic cataract after firecracker injury
CATARACT.description: Iridodialysis is the result of a tear in the iris root. It may be repaired surgically or with cosmetic contact lenses if large or symptomatic. This cataract's rosette pattern is classically seen after contusion injuries. It is due to separation of lens fibers around lens sutures

CATARACT.title: Mature Cataract
CATARACT.description: This patient with mature cataract (nuclear sclerotic and cortical changes) had only bare light perception vision.

images.alt: this elderly female presented with a mature cataract in the right eye

CATARACT.title: Mature cortical cataract
CATARACT.description: In a mature cortical cataract, also known as a "white cataract," the entire lens cortex has become opacified. Water clefts are visible as less opaque radial wedges within the lens. These lenses can swell as a result of increased water uptake, at which point they are called intumescent cataracts.

CATARACT.title: Mittendorf dot
CATARACT.description: A Mittendorf dot is a small, circular opacity on the posterior lens capsule, classically nasal in location, which represents the anterior attachment of the hyaloid artery. The hyaloid artery is present during gestation and typically regresses completely. Failure to do so can lead to benign findings, such as a Mittendorf dot or a Bergmeister's papilla, or pathologic changes as seen in persistent fetal vasculature syndrome.

CATARACT.title: Morgagnian cataract with absent cortex
CATARACT.contributor: Christopher A. Kirkpatrick, MD and Anna Kitzmann, MD
CATARACT.description: A Morgagnian cataract is a hypermature cataract in which there is typically liquefaction of the lens cortex with dense sclerosis of the nucleus. This presentation is typical for the brunescent lens nucleus that is inferiorly displaced within the capsule, but atypical in that there is no lens cortex remaining, the previously liquified cortex has migrated through the intact capsule, leaving only a sunken, hard nucleus in an empty capsular bag

CATARACT.title: Ocular Syphilis Presenting with Posterior Subcapsular Cataract
CATARACT.description: A 50-year-old male presented with 10 days of progressive vision loss in the left eye (OS) as well as fevers, fatigue, and unintentional weight loss. Visual acuity was hand motion OS. Slitlamp examination showed 1+ anterior vitreous cells. On funduscopy, he had severe optic disc edema with 360 degrees of peripapillary cotton wool spots and nerve fiber layer hemorrhages, along with a serous retinal detachment with peripapillary yellowish inflammation in the outer retina around the disc (A). He was found to have active syphilis with AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome). He was treated with penicillin at that time and anti-retroviral therapy was ultimately initiated by the infectious diseases service

images.alt: Syphilis Presenting with Posterior Subcapsular Cataract

CATARACT.title: Persistent pupillary membranes (1)
CATARACT.description: Persistent pupillary membranes are the result of remnants of the tunica vasculosa lentis, a vascular network that surround the lens during embryogenesis. They can vary in presentation from a few fine iris strands bridging the pupil to intricate webs with attachments to the lens. Intricate webs with attachments to the lens

CATARACT.title: Persistent Pupillary Membrane (2)
CATARACT.description: Persistent pupillary membrane is an embryologic remnant of the tunica vasculosa lentis, the vascular bed that surrounded the lens during fetal development. This is an atypical presentation with only one single, fine iris strand that has fibrosed to the anterior lens capsule.

CATARACT.title: Posterior subcapsular cataract
CATARACT.description: This patient is a diabetic male whose vision decreased dramatically over the course of about a month. Glare was a significant complaint.

CATARACT.title: Posterior subcapsular cataract
CATARACT.description: A 53-year-old female with a past medical history of Type 1 diabetes mellitus presented for blurry vision in her left eye. On exam, she was noted to have granular lenticular opacities adjacent to the posterior capsule of the natural crystalline lens in the right eye. A diagnosis of posterior subcapsular cataract (PSC) was made. Factors such as diabetes mellitus, chlorpromazine use, or corticosteroids increase the risk of PSC formation. [1] In comparison to other cataract types, glare and decreased near acuity may be more common presenting symptoms. These types of cataracts are best viewed with slit lamp biomicroscopy retroillumination; care should be taken to achieve line of focus on the posterior capsule, or the cataract can be readily missed

CATARACT.title: Silicone oil droplet on intraocular lens (IOL)
CATARACT.contributor: Christopher Kirkpatrick, MD and Anna Kitzmann, MD
CATARACT.description: Silicone oil is a commonly used material in retina surgery, typically vitrectomy; it’s adherence to silicone IOLs is a widely recognized phenomenon and use of a silicone IOL is contraindicated in patients that have had or are at high risk of needing a vitrectomy. Silicone oil on an IOL is seen as variable sized droplets that are adherent to the surface of the IOL. These can be visually significant to varying degrees based on size and location of the droplets. The picture represents a patient who underwent cataract surgery with placement of a 3-piece silicone IOL about 3 years prior to presenting with a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment requiring pars plana vitrectomy with silicone oil placement and scleral buckle. He later presented with this large silicone oil droplet adherent to the posterior surface of his IOL. He went on to have an IOL exchange with silicone oil removal

CATARACT.title: Traumatic aniridia and cataract
CATARACT.description: This patient was referred to another ophthalmologist for cataract extraction and insertion of a pupillary prosthesis.

CATARACT.contributor: Dr. Swaranjit Singh Bhatti, Bhatti Eye Clinic
CATARACT.description: This is a traumatic rosette cataract seen in fundal retroillumination (against the fundal red glow) on the slit lamp.The leaf like "rosette" pattern is pathognomonic of a traumatic cataract and the clear zone outside the affect lens lamellae indicate that the trauma occurred several years before as clear lens fibres have been laid down in the periphery subsequently.

CATARACT.title: "Y-suture" Cataract
CATARACT.description: This is a 46-year-old male with a promient Y-suture cataract. This is a congenital lens opacity that occurs at the location of closure of the fetal lenticular nucleus. The anterior sutures are in the shape of a Y and the posterior sutures are an inverted Y. These are rarely visually signficant

images.alt: promient Y-suture cataract seen in the middle of the eye

CATARACT.title: Cerulean Cataract
CATARACT.description: Cerulean cataracts are composed of small bluish dot-like opacities in the peripheral lens cortex. They usually do not cause visual symptoms. This patient also has a dense central posterior subcapsular cataract which was visually significant.

images.alt: Cerulean cataract looking imagine the blue color on tarnished copper

CATARACT.title: Retained Lens Fragment
CATARACT.description: Posted: 06/03/2024 A 72-year-old man presented one week after uncomplicated cataract surgery for progressive photophobia and blurry vision in the surgical eye. On exam, there was a retained lens fragment in the anterior chamber. Small pieces of nuclear or cortical lens material can sometimes be hidden in the ciliary sulcus at the end of cataract surgery. Patients present with an inflammatory picture. Often times cortical material can be observed and treated medically with anti-inflammatory topical treatment. Nuclear material, as in this case, however, often requires surgical intervention with removal of the lenticular remnant

CATARACT.title: Iris coloboma
CATARACT.description: Posted: 06/04/2024 A 20-year-old man presented for routine follow up of congenital nystagmus. Anterior segment examination revealed an iris coloboma in both eyes. In the right eye, there was concomitant congenital cataract. Colobomas are developmental defects that result from incomplete closure of the embryonic fissure. Colobomas can involve the iris, ciliary body, choroid, retina, and optic nerve. Colobomas are located in the inferonasal quadrant

CATARACT.title: Late Capsular Block with Posterior Capsular Fibrosis
CATARACT.description: Posted: 06/04/2024 A 44-year-old pseudophakic female presented with progressive worsening vision after uncomplicated cataract surgery 8 years prior. The patient has a history of proliferative diabetic retinopathy with prior vitrectomy and developed cataracts early. On exam, there were thick posterior capsular opacities with a capsular block appearance and fluid noted beyond the intraocular lens.

CATARACT.title: Opacification of Hydrophilic Intraocular Lens
CATARACT.description: Posted: 06/27/2024 A 64-year-old man with a history of bilateral pseudophakia and partial-thickness corneal transplantation in both eyes presented for progressive vision loss in the left eye. The patient underwent uncomplicated cataract surgery several years ago and then subsequently, more recently, had uncomplicated Descemet membrane endothelial keratoplasty (DMEK) for Fuchs' endothelial dystrophy. On exam, there was a centered intraocular lens in the capsular bag. The intraocular lens had a stippled central opacification extending through the visual axis on the anterior lens surface. On further investigation, the intraocular lens was confirmed to be an Akreos MI60 hydrophilic lens. It was suspected that the lens had opacified after exposure to intraocular gas following DMEK surgery

CATARACT.title: Vitreous strand to paracentesis causing subtle peaked pupil early in case
CATARACT.description: Posted: 08/22/2024 Here is an example of a subtle peaked pupil early during cataract surgery. The patient has an essentially invisible strand ov vitreous that is going to the paracentesis from a peripheral point which is causing peaking of the pupil. Vitreous prolapse that extends to a paracentesis such as in this case can cause peaking of the pupil. In this case the vitreous presented early in the case making the surgery very difficult. The caractous lens was removed by converting to an ECCE supplemented with an anterior vittectomy.

images.alt: Vitreous prolapse that extends to a paracentesis such as in this case can cause peaking of the pupil.  In this case the vitreous presented early in the case making the surgery very difficult.   The caractous lens was removed by converting to an ECCE supplemented with an anterior vittectomy.

CATARACT.title: Calcific Deposits on an Intraocular Lens
CATARACT.contributor: Christian A. Mays, MD; Erin A. Boese, MD
CATARACT.description: Posted: 01/10/2025 A 72-year-old woman presented with widely fluctuating visual acuity following an uncomplicated phacoemulsification combined with 360° gonioscopy-assisted transluminal trabeculotomy (GATT). Post-operatively, her course was notable for a 2.5mm hyphema, which cleared within a week. On follow-up examination at three months, she had a persistent intracapsular hemorrhage with a superficial layer of dehemoglobinized blood in her right eye (Figure 1A). She underwent a neodymium-aluminum-garnet (Nd:YAG) capsulotomy with immediate clearance of the blood (Figure 1B). Two weeks following the capsulotomy, she had complete resolution of her fluctuating visual acuity

images.alt: A 72-year-old woman presented with widely fluctuating visual acuity following an uncomplicated phacoemulsification combined with 360° gonioscopy-assisted transluminal trabeculotomy (GATT). Post-operatively, her course was notable for a 2.5mm hyphema, which cleared within a week. On follow-up examination at three months, she had a persistent intracapsular hemorrhage with a superficial layer of dehemoglobinized blood in her right eye (Figure 1A). She underwent a neodymium-aluminum-garnet (Nd:YAG) capsulotomy with immediate clearance of the blood (Figure 1B).

CATARACT.title: Layered intracapsular hemorrhage following phacoemulsification GATT
CATARACT.contributor: Peter H. Sanchez MD; Bilal Ahmed MD; Thomas Oetting MD;
CATARACT.description: Posted: 12/09/2024 A 74-year-old female with history of proliferative diabetic retinopathy in both eyes (OU), lamellar hole in the left eye (OS), POAG status post Ahmed tube in the right eye (OD), full thickness macular hole OD status post vitrectomy, and cataract extraction with implantation of AMO 9002, 3-piece silicone intraocular lenses OU 15 years ago was referred for a several month history of blurry and decreased vision OS. She had already undergone YAG-laser capsulotomy OS by an outside provider without improvement in her visual acuity. On presentation, her vision was 20/200 OS. Her exam was notable for granular, white deposits on the posterior surface of the lens OS. She had already undergone explantation of the OD silicone lens for a similar process. She was consented for intraocular lens exchange OS with a MA50BM lens

images.alt: Retroillumation of calcium deposits on a 3-piece silicone intraocular lens.
Broad beam illumination of calcium deposits on the posterior surface of a 3-piece silicone intraocular lens.

CATARACT.title: Posterior Polar Cataract with Traumatic Posterior Capsule Rupture
CATARACT.contributor: Nicolas J Heckenlaible MD; Patrick J Donegan MD; Lindsay M De Andrade MD
CATARACT.description: Posted: 06/20/2025 A 16-year-old male with a known history of bilateral posterior polar cataracts and baseline visual acuity of 20/20-1 without correction in each eye sustained a traumatic impact to the right eye from a thrown water bottle. On initial evaluation after trauma, his visual acuity was decreased to 20/200 without correction (20/30-2 with pinhole). Anterior segment exam revealed multiple corneal abrasions in the visual axis of the right eye but was otherwise unremarkable. He was prescribed erythromycin ointment and advised to return in 1 week. He was lost to follow up and returned six months later with continued decrease in vision in his right eye. At this time, his visual acuity was 20/200 without correction (20/60 with pinhole)

images.alt: Diffuse illumination slit lamp photograph of a posterior polar cataract with posterior capsular rupture.
Slit lamp photograph showing retro-illumination of a posterior polar cataract with posterior capsular rupture.

CATARACT.title: Unique Electric Cataract
CATARACT.contributor: Thomas D. Meram, MD; Ryan J. Diel, MD
CATARACT.photographer: Meghan C. Menzel, CRA; Michael T. Edrington, CRA
CATARACT.description: Posted: 06/02/2025 Slit lamp photos of a 32-year-old male with cataracts sustained after 270-volt electrocution injury. The cataracts appeared as a ring within the lens nucleus in a circumferential pattern following the natural lens architecture. Patient had no subjective visual symptoms. Appearance of the cataracts was stable at 2 days and 6 months post injury. The patient has no known history of congenital cataracts; however, a baseline exam was not available. Slit lamp photo at two days post injury

Slit lamp photo at six months post injury.

CATARACT.title: Subluxated posterior chamber intraocular lens implant
CATARACT.contributor: Noor-Us-Sabah Ahmad, MD; Chad Y. Lewis, MD, MPH; Thomas A. Oetting, MS, MD
CATARACT.description: Posted: 06/26/2025 A 70-year-old man presented to the clinic 2 years after right-sided cataract extraction with a posterior chamber intra-ocular lens (PCIOL) implant performed at an outside hospital. He reported blurriness as well as seeing a "half-moon shadow" in his right eye vision. Slit lamp examination of his right eye showed inferonasal subluxation of his PCIOL along with 2+ posterior capsular opacification and cortical material within the capsular bag. He was taken to the OR for an IOL exchange procedure. Intra-operatively, a posterior capsular tear was encountered which was complicated by the IOL protruding out of the tear and vitreous prolapse. He underwent IOL explantation and anterior vitrectomy followed by placement of a new IOL in the sulcus with capture by the anterior capsule

images.alt: Retroillumination on slit lamp examination showed inferonasal subluxation of PCIOL along with 2+ posterior capsular opacification

CATARACT.title: Cataract with cortical vacuoles

CONTACT LENS.title: Anterior polar cataract
CONTACT LENS.description: Anterior polar cataracts are congenital opacities involving the anterior capsule and subcapsular cortex. They are typically small, bilateral, symmetric, non-progressive, and not visually significant. The patient in these photographs had anterior polar cataracts that were more prominent in the left eye than the right. Only the left cataract was visually significant. OD - Slit Lamp

images.alt: Anterior Polar Catatact Slit Lamp OD
Anterior Polar Catatact Slit Lamp OS

CONTACT LENS.title: Anterior subcapsular cataract
CONTACT LENS.description: Anterior subcapsular cataracts (ASC) form after anterior lens epithelial cells become necrotic from a variety of causes including iritis, keratitis, inflammation associated with atopic dermatitis, irradiation, or electrical burns. The opacification of the lens is due to a migration of adjacent epithelial cells into the damaged area and subsequent transformation of these cells into a plaque of multiple layers of myofibroblasts. The most posterior layer of these cells remain epithelial cells and will produce a new lens capsule. Over time the myofibroblasts resolve leaving a wrinkled appearance to the lens capsule. A duplication cataract occurs when a cortical cataract develops in the same area as the ASC.

CONTACT LENS.title: Chlorpromazine-induced cataract
CONTACT LENS.description: Stellate, anterior subcapsular cataract with granular, brown deposits along the suture lines in a patient taking chlorpromazine.

CONTACT LENS.title: Circle Contact Lens
CONTACT LENS.description: Circle contact lenses are soft contact lenses with a limbal ring that is larger than the patient's visible iris. The look is very dramatic and is favored by anime enthusiasts for making people look more doll or anime character-like. The Etafilcon A® lens (in photo) is a 1-day replacement lens that is currently the only FDA-approved circle lens in the US.

On exam he had a unilateral anterior polar cataract combined with central posterior subcapsular cataract with mild cortical changes. He elected to proceed with cataract extraction.

CONTACT LENS.title: Glaukomflecken and iris atrophy after acute angle closure glaucoma
CONTACT LENS.description: Glaukomflecken are small anterior subcapsular opacities secondary to lens epithelial necrosis resulting from acute angle closure glaucoma. These photographs from two different patients show central glaukomflecken and iris atrophy secondary to prior episodes of acute angle closure glaucoma..

CONTACT LENS.title: Lens material in the anterior chamber causing chronic uveitis
CONTACT LENS.contributor: Jesse Vislisel, MD; Anna Kitzmann, MD
CONTACT LENS.description: Lens material can cause intraocular inflammation when not isolated by the lens capsule. This patient was referred with chronic, refractory uveitis of unknown etiology, but on exam he was found to have a large piece of displaced lens material in the anterior chamber. In the photographs, a large piece of cataractous lens nuclear material is present inferiorly. The anterior chamber uveitis is not easily visible, but the corneal edema and Descemet's folds can be visualized using the slit beam.

CONTACT LENS.title: Makeup on toric soft contact lens
CONTACT LENS.description: Many makeup wearers choose to line the inside of their eyelids posterior to the lash line with eyeliner. If the patient is a contact lens wearer, as in this image, the surface integrity of the contact lens can be compromised resulting in increased risk of infection as bacteria more easily bond to a disrupted surface. It can also decrease comfort of the lens and cause irritation of the palpebral conjunctiva as blinking causes the conjunctiva to rub across the roughened surface. The effect can heightened in a toric contact lens wearer since the rotational stabilization required for the toric optics prevents the lens from rotating and keeps the irritant rubbing on the same tissues. In addition to the contact lens complications, makeup can block the meibomian glands and exacerbate dry eye, the effect is worsened if the eyeliner used is waterproof.

CONTACT LENS.title: Suture iris reconstruction using McCannel suture technique
CONTACT LENS.description: This patient had persistent mydriasis and traumatic cataract after blunt ocular trauma. These photographs show his appearance shortly after cataract extraction and suture iris reconstruction using the McCannel suture technique and Siepser slipknots.

CONTACT LENS.title: Suture iris reconstruction using McCannel suture technique
CONTACT LENS.description: This patient had persistent mydriasis and traumatic cataract after blunt ocular trauma. These photographs show his appearance shortly after cataract extraction and suture iris reconstruction using the McCannel suture technique and Siepser slipknots.

CONTACT LENS.title: McCannel suture scaffold to reconstruct the iris plane
CONTACT LENS.contributor: Jeffrey Welder, MD; Elizabeth Tegins, MD
CONTACT LENS.description: McCannel suture scaffold used to maintain silicone oil in the vitreous cavity after trauma resulting in aphakia, total iris loss and retinal detachment.

CONTACT LENS.title: Morgagnian cataract
CONTACT LENS.description: Morgagnian cataracts are advanced cortical cataracts in which the nucleus is freely mobile within liquefied cortex. In this photo, a brunescent nucleus can be seen sunken to the bottom of the capsular bag with the white, liquefied cortex visible superiorly.

CONTACT LENS.title: Posterior Polar Cataract
CONTACT LENS.description: Posterior polar cataracts are a form of congenital cataract commonly associated with posterior capsule changes. They can be autosomal dominant or sporadic and are more commonly bilateral. They are rarely visually significant and are usually stable, but may progress over time. This 42-year-old patient was referred from an outside provider with complaints of blurred vision at distance and near in addition to being bothered by glare. He had 2.5 mm concentric posterior polar opacities in both eyes and elected to undergo cataract extraction

CONTACT LENS.title: Soft Contact Lens
CONTACT LENS.description: Monthly soft contact lenses are a staple for anyone involved in prescribing contact lenses. The lenses should move a small amount with the blink, particularly on up gaze. A lens that moves excessively may be uncomfortable and may result in variable vision, but if the patient is happy with it, excessive movement is not a health problem.

images.alt: brown eye with soft contact lens
brown eye with soft contact lens with focuses light

CONTACT LENS.title: Toric Soft Contact Lens
CONTACT LENS.description: Toric soft contact lenses have two powers built into them in order to correct regular astigmatism. The lenses generally have a laser marking to aid the clinician in evaluating the fit. In the Comfilcon® lenses pictured, there is a single marking at 6 o'clock on the lens (seen as a bright linear reflection as light artifact reflects off the laser marking in the picture). If the marking is rotated away from the 6 o'clock position, as in the second image, more analysis is required. If the marking stabilizes in that location you can note it and move on if the vision is good. However, if the vision is not acceptable, you can compensate the axis using the LARS rule- Left Add, Right Subtract

images.alt: Dilated funduscopic examination showed severe, diffuse optic atrophy OD and bow-tie (band) optic atrophy OS

CONTACT LENS.title: Typical Corneal Rigid Gas Permeable (RGP) Contact Lens
CONTACT LENS.description: These two photos are of the same, very well fit, RGP. The first is taken using cobalt blue light with a Wratten yellow filter and fluorescein where the second is taken without the use of a Wratten filter. This lens is nicely lid-attached with a slightly superior position in primary gaze and an even aligned relationship to the cornea. The lens should move with the blink- the larger the lens, the less it will move, but a corneal lens should always have some movement.

images.alt: Rigid Gas Permeable (RGP) contact lens, good fit, cobalt blue with Wratten yellow filter and fluorescein
Rigid Gas Permeable (RGP) contact lens, good fit, cobalt blue,  yellow filter and fluorescein

CONTACT LENS.contributor: Jesse Vislisel, MD, Tressa Larson, MA, OD
CONTACT LENS.description: The Visian Implantable Collamer Lens (ICL) is a sulcus-supported phakic intraocular lens implant designed to be placed in the posterior chamber between the iris and natural crystalline lens. These photographs show the appearance of a Visian ICL used to correct myopia. The implanted lens can be seen in the slit beam (white arrow) just anterior to the natural crystalline lens (blue arrow). Read the related case report for more information about phakic intraocular lenses.

CONTACT LENS.contributor: Lauren E. Hock, MD and A. Tim Johnson, MD, PhD
CONTACT LENS.description: Lensectomy is the definitive treatment for both phacomorphic angle closure and pupillary block secondary to lens dislocation. Slit lamp photograph of the right eye shows 3+ diffuse injection with the crystalline lens filling the anterior chamber, lenticulocorneal touch, stromal edema, 360 degree iridocorneal touch, and posterior capsule opacification. CONTACT LENS.title: Congenital lamellar / zonular cataract in a child
Coppock Cataract
CONTACT LENS.description: This is called a "Coppock cataract," also known as a "central pulverulent cataract." It refers to a pulverulent disc-like opactiy involving the embryonal and fetal nucleus with many tiny white dots in the lamellar portion of the lens. It is usually bilateral and dominantly inherited.

CONTACT LENS.description: This patient had mature cataractous lenses in both eyes that had dislocated completely and were freely floating in the vitreous. Of interest, he experienced severe vision loss when lying down as the lenses settled over his macula. Due to significant axial myopia, he only required +4.00 D of lens correction in each eye to achieve 20/20 acuity

CONTACT LENS.title: Mittendorf dot
CONTACT LENS.description: A Mittendorf dot is a small, circular opacity on the posterior lens capsule, classically nasal in location, which represents the anterior attachment of the hyaloid artery. The hyaloid artery is present during gestation and typically regresses completely. Failure to do so can lead to benign findings, such as a Mittendorf dot or a Bergmeister's papilla, or pathologic changes as seen in persistent fetal vasculature syndrome.

CONTACT LENS.title: Morgagnian cataract with absent cortex
CONTACT LENS.contributor: Christopher A. Kirkpatrick, MD and Anna Kitzmann, MD
CONTACT LENS.description: A Morgagnian cataract is a hypermature cataract in which there is typically liquefaction of the lens cortex with dense sclerosis of the nucleus. This presentation is typical for the brunescent lens nucleus that is inferiorly displaced within the capsule, but atypical in that there is no lens cortex remaining, the previously liquified cortex has migrated through the intact capsule, leaving only a sunken, hard nucleus in an empty capsular bag

images.alt: Diffuse illumination slit lamp photograph of an oil-droplet cataract showing central nuclear yellow opacity of the lens with dark clearing surrounding the oil-droplet.

Optical section slit lamp photograph of the right eye showing a 3+ oil-droplet cataract with the central yellow opacified nucleus surrounded by an area of dark clearing followed by the cortical and capsular layers anteriorly.

CONTACT LENS.title: Persistent pupillary membranes (1)
CONTACT LENS.description: Persistent pupillary membranes are the result of remnants of the tunica vasculosa lentis, a vascular network that surround the lens during embryogenesis. They can vary in presentation from a few fine iris strands bridging the pupil to intricate webs with attachments to the lens. Intricate webs with attachments to the lens

Related Atals Entry: Persistent Pupillary Membrane

CONTACT LENS.title: Persistent Pupillary Membrane (2)
CONTACT LENS.description: Persistent pupillary membrane is an embryologic remnant of the tunica vasculosa lentis, the vascular bed that surrounded the lens during fetal development. This is an atypical presentation with only one single, fine iris strand that has fibrosed to the anterior lens capsule.

images.alt: external photo showing Persistent pupillary membrane is an embryologic remnant of the tunica vasculosa lentis

CONTACT LENS.title: Posterior subcapsular cataract
CONTACT LENS.description: This patient is a diabetic male whose vision decreased dramatically over the course of about a month. Glare was a significant complaint.

CONTACT LENS.title: Silicone oil droplet on intraocular lens (IOL)
CONTACT LENS.contributor: Christopher Kirkpatrick, MD and Anna Kitzmann, MD
CONTACT LENS.description: Silicone oil is a commonly used material in retina surgery, typically vitrectomy; it’s adherence to silicone IOLs is a widely recognized phenomenon and use of a silicone IOL is contraindicated in patients that have had or are at high risk of needing a vitrectomy. Silicone oil on an IOL is seen as variable sized droplets that are adherent to the surface of the IOL. These can be visually significant to varying degrees based on size and location of the droplets. The picture represents a patient who underwent cataract surgery with placement of a 3-piece silicone IOL about 3 years prior to presenting with a rhegmatogenous retinal detachment requiring pars plana vitrectomy with silicone oil placement and scleral buckle. He later presented with this large silicone oil droplet adherent to the posterior surface of his IOL. He went on to have an IOL exchange with silicone oil removal

CONTACT LENS.title: Traumatic aniridia and cataract
CONTACT LENS.description: This patient was referred to another ophthalmologist for cataract extraction and insertion of a pupillary prosthesis.

CONTACT LENS.title: Traumatic cataract with iridodialysis and lens coloboma
CONTACT LENS.description: This is a traumatic cataract with an iridodialysis (separation of the iris from it's attachment to the ciliary body) from a blunt injury during childhood. There is an anterior cortical cataract with evidence of capsular compromise and adhesion of the displaced iris to this area. There is also a lens pseudo-coloboma (lessened convexity along the equator) inferotemporally secondary to zonular dehiscence (not shown).

CONTACT LENS.title: Traumatic rosette cataract
CONTACT LENS.contributor: Dr. Swaranjit Singh Bhatti, Bhatti Eye Clinic
CONTACT LENS.description: This is a traumatic rosette cataract seen in fundal retroillumination (against the fundal red glow) on the slit lamp.The leaf like "rosette" pattern is pathognomonic of a traumatic cataract and the clear zone outside the affect lens lamellae indicate that the trauma occurred several years before as clear lens fibres have been laid down in the periphery subsequently.

images.alt: traumatic rosette cataract seen in fundal retroillumination

CONTACT LENS.title: "Y-suture" Cataract
CONTACT LENS.description: This is a 46-year-old male with a promient Y-suture cataract. This is a congenital lens opacity that occurs at the location of closure of the fetal lenticular nucleus. The anterior sutures are in the shape of a Y and the posterior sutures are an inverted Y. These are rarely visually signficant

images.alt: promient Y-suture cataract seen in the middle of the eye

CONTACT LENS.title: Corneal and lenticular pigmentation from long-term chlorpromazine use
CONTACT LENS.contributor: Zachary Q. Mortensen, MD; Ryan J. Diel, MD; A. Tim Johnson, MD
CONTACT LENS.description: Corneal and lenticular pigmentation from long-term chlorpromazine use 59-year-old male with history of schizophrenia and long-term chlorpromazine (thorazine) treatment. His ocular exam is notable for fine pigment deposition in the posterior corneal stroma and endothelium. In addition, there is pigmentation in a stellate pattern on the anterior lens and lens capsule. This rarely causes a decrease in visual acuity. These findings are characteristic of long-term thorazine use and are suspected to be related to dose and duration of treatment. It is recommended that persons undergoing long-term treatment with thorazine have regular eye examinations

slit lamp showing eye after long term chlorpromazine use showing  blue-gray dyspigmentation

CONTACT LENS.title: Visualization of posterior persistent fetal vasculature following lens subluxation
CONTACT LENS.contributor: Mahsaw Mansoor, MD, Ryan J. Diel, MD, Jaclyn M. Haugsdal, MD

CONTACT LENS.title: Retained Lens Fragment
CONTACT LENS.description: Posted: 06/03/2024 A 72-year-old man presented one week after uncomplicated cataract surgery for progressive photophobia and blurry vision in the surgical eye. On exam, there was a retained lens fragment in the anterior chamber. Small pieces of nuclear or cortical lens material can sometimes be hidden in the ciliary sulcus at the end of cataract surgery. Patients present with an inflammatory picture. Often times cortical material can be observed and treated medically with anti-inflammatory topical treatment. Nuclear material, as in this case, however, often requires surgical intervention with removal of the lenticular remnant

CONTACT LENS.title: Iris coloboma
CONTACT LENS.description: Posted: 06/04/2024 A 20-year-old man presented for routine follow up of congenital nystagmus. Anterior segment examination revealed an iris coloboma in both eyes. In the right eye, there was concomitant congenital cataract. Colobomas are developmental defects that result from incomplete closure of the embryonic fissure. Colobomas can involve the iris, ciliary body, choroid, retina, and optic nerve. Colobomas are located in the inferonasal quadrant

CONTACT LENS.title: Late Capsular Block with Posterior Capsular Fibrosis
CONTACT LENS.description: Posted: 06/04/2024 A 44-year-old pseudophakic female presented with progressive worsening vision after uncomplicated cataract surgery 8 years prior. The patient has a history of proliferative diabetic retinopathy with prior vitrectomy and developed cataracts early. On exam, there were thick posterior capsular opacities with a capsular block appearance and fluid noted beyond the intraocular lens.

CONTACT LENS.title: Calcific Deposits on an Intraocular Lens
CONTACT LENS.contributor: Christian A. Mays, MD; Erin A. Boese, MD
CONTACT LENS.description: Posted: 01/10/2025 A 72-year-old woman presented with widely fluctuating visual acuity following an uncomplicated phacoemulsification combined with 360° gonioscopy-assisted transluminal trabeculotomy (GATT). Post-operatively, her course was notable for a 2.5mm hyphema, which cleared within a week. On follow-up examination at three months, she had a persistent intracapsular hemorrhage with a superficial layer of dehemoglobinized blood in her right eye (Figure 1A). She underwent a neodymium-aluminum-garnet (Nd:YAG) capsulotomy with immediate clearance of the blood (Figure 1B). Two weeks following the capsulotomy, she had complete resolution of her fluctuating visual acuity

images.alt: A 72-year-old woman presented with widely fluctuating visual acuity following an uncomplicated phacoemulsification combined with 360° gonioscopy-assisted transluminal trabeculotomy (GATT). Post-operatively, her course was notable for a 2.5mm hyphema, which cleared within a week. On follow-up examination at three months, she had a persistent intracapsular hemorrhage with a superficial layer of dehemoglobinized blood in her right eye (Figure 1A). She underwent a neodymium-aluminum-garnet (Nd:YAG) capsulotomy with immediate clearance of the blood (Figure 1B).

CONTACT LENS.title: Layered intracapsular hemorrhage following phacoemulsification GATT
CONTACT LENS.contributor: Peter H. Sanchez MD; Bilal Ahmed MD; Thomas Oetting MD;
CONTACT LENS.description: Posted: 12/09/2024 A 74-year-old female with history of proliferative diabetic retinopathy in both eyes (OU), lamellar hole in the left eye (OS), POAG status post Ahmed tube in the right eye (OD), full thickness macular hole OD status post vitrectomy, and cataract extraction with implantation of AMO 9002, 3-piece silicone intraocular lenses OU 15 years ago was referred for a several month history of blurry and decreased vision OS. She had already undergone YAG-laser capsulotomy OS by an outside provider without improvement in her visual acuity. On presentation, her vision was 20/200 OS. Her exam was notable for granular, white deposits on the posterior surface of the lens OS. She had already undergone explantation of the OD silicone lens for a similar process. She was consented for intraocular lens exchange OS with a MA50BM lens

Broad beam illumination of calcium deposits on the posterior surface of a 3-piece silicone intraocular lens.

CONTACT LENS.title: Nocardia farcinica keratitis in a contact lens wearer
CONTACT LENS.description: There is prominent ciliary flush, diffuse conjunctival injection, and a superior pannus.

images.alt: Slit lamp photography of the right eye. This photograph shows a moderate amount of white blood cell recruitment surrounding the stromal opacities in addition to small, branching-type lesions extending from the stromal opacities. Several satellite lesions are present

Slit lamp photography of the right eye. This photograph demonstrates a focal lesion in the nasal mid-periphery without feathery borders but with surrounding inflammation. Ciliary flush is evident with diffuse 2+ injection. There are complete epithelial defects overlying these lesions (not photographed).

CONTACT LENS.title: Posterior Polar Cataract with Traumatic Posterior Capsule Rupture
CONTACT LENS.contributor: Nicolas J Heckenlaible MD; Patrick J Donegan MD; Lindsay M De Andrade MD
CONTACT LENS.description: Posted: 06/20/2025 A 16-year-old male with a known history of bilateral posterior polar cataracts and baseline visual acuity of 20/20-1 without correction in each eye sustained a traumatic impact to the right eye from a thrown water bottle. On initial evaluation after trauma, his visual acuity was decreased to 20/200 without correction (20/30-2 with pinhole). Anterior segment exam revealed multiple corneal abrasions in the visual axis of the right eye but was otherwise unremarkable. He was prescribed erythromycin ointment and advised to return in 1 week. He was lost to follow up and returned six months later with continued decrease in vision in his right eye. At this time, his visual acuity was 20/200 without correction (20/60 with pinhole)

images.alt: Diffuse illumination slit lamp photograph of a posterior polar cataract with posterior capsular rupture.
Slit lamp photograph showing retro-illumination of a posterior polar cataract with posterior capsular rupture.

CONTACT LENS.title: Unique Electric Cataract
CONTACT LENS.contributor: Thomas D. Meram, MD; Ryan J. Diel, MD
CONTACT LENS.photographer: Meghan C. Menzel, CRA; Michael T. Edrington, CRA
CONTACT LENS.description: Posted: 06/02/2025 Slit lamp photos of a 32-year-old male with cataracts sustained after 270-volt electrocution injury. The cataracts appeared as a ring within the lens nucleus in a circumferential pattern following the natural lens architecture. Patient had no subjective visual symptoms. Appearance of the cataracts was stable at 2 days and 6 months post injury. The patient has no known history of congenital cataracts; however, a baseline exam was not available. Slit lamp photo at two days post injury

images.alt: Slit lamp photo at two days post injury.
Slit lamp photo at six months post injury.

CONTACT LENS.title: Subluxated posterior chamber intraocular lens implant
CONTACT LENS.contributor: Noor-Us-Sabah Ahmad, MD; Chad Y. Lewis, MD, MPH; Thomas A. Oetting, MS, MD
CONTACT LENS.description: Posted: 06/26/2025 A 70-year-old man presented to the clinic 2 years after right-sided cataract extraction with a posterior chamber intra-ocular lens (PCIOL) implant performed at an outside hospital. He reported blurriness as well as seeing a "half-moon shadow" in his right eye vision. Slit lamp examination of his right eye showed inferonasal subluxation of his PCIOL along with 2+ posterior capsular opacification and cortical material within the capsular bag. He was taken to the OR for an IOL exchange procedure. Intra-operatively, a posterior capsular tear was encountered which was complicated by the IOL protruding out of the tear and vitreous prolapse. He underwent IOL explantation and anterior vitrectomy followed by placement of a new IOL in the sulcus with capture by the anterior capsule

images.alt: Retroillumination on slit lamp examination showed inferonasal subluxation of PCIOL along with 2+ posterior capsular opacification
Diffuse illumination on slit lamp examination showed inferonasal subluxation of PCIOL

CORNEA.title: Acanthamoeba keratitis
CORNEA.contributor: Jesse Vislisel, MD; Jordan Graff, MD; Meagan Seay, DO
CORNEA.photographer: Brice Critser, CRA; Stefani Karakas, CRA; Nasreen Syed, MD; Meagan Seay, DO
CORNEA.description: Acanthamoeba keratitis is a rare parasitic infection of the cornea that primarily occurs in contact lens wearers. The infection may be limited to the epithelium in its early stages, resulting in epithelial dendrites and punctate epitheliopathy. Later stromal involvement classically results in a partial or complete paracentral ring infiltrate, radial perineuritis, and pain out of proportion to the appearance on exam. Scleritis and uveitis may also be present. Figure 1: Corneal ring infiltrate in a patient with Acanthamoeba keratitis. The diagnosis was confirmed by confocal microscopy (Figure 3)

images.alt: Concentric ring infiltrate in a contact lens wearer with early Acanthamoeba keratitis
Concentric ring infiltrate in a contact lens wearer with early Acanthamoeba keratitis
Concentric ring infiltrate in a contact lens wearer with early Acanthamoeba keratitis
Figure 4: Epitheliitis with marked radial perineuritis secondary to Acanthamoeba infection.
Figure 4b: Epitheliitis with marked radial perineuritis secondary to Acanthamoeba infection.
H&E stain demonstrates a classic example of the double-walled cyst structure of Acanthamoeba.

CORNEA.title: Acquired interface fluid after DSAEK graft rejection
CORNEA.contributor: Jesse Vislisel, MD; Mark Greiner, MD
CORNEA.description: Interface fluid between a corneal endothelial graft and host cornea is commonly seen intraoperatively and in the immediate post-operative period, but resolves as the graft pumps fluid away from the interface. This patient had massive corneal edema after an episode of acute allograft rejection of her DSAEK graft, resulting in acquired fluid accumulation in the graft-host interface. This fluid is visible in the slit beam as a black crescent between the graft and host tissue.

CORNEA.contributor: Jesse Vislisel, MD; Wallace L.M. Alward, MD

CORNEA.title: Alkali chemical burn
CORNEA.description: This patient experienced a severe alkali chemical injury resulting in corneal opacification, pannus, and symblepharon formation. These photographs were taken 6 months after the injury.

CORNEA.title: AlphaCor keratoprosthesis
CORNEA.photographer: Stephanie Karakas, CRA and Tracy Aly, CRA
CORNEA.description: The AlphaCor is a type of keratoprosthesis implant used for patients that are not candidates for traditional penetrating keratoplasty. In our practice at the

CORNEA.title: Polymorphic amyloid degeneration of the cornea
CORNEA.description: Polymorphic amyloid degeneration is a bilateral corneal degeneration that develops later in life. It results in refractile, stellate flecks or irregular filaments in the mid to deep corneal stroma with intervening clear spaces. These photographs show the appearance of polymorphic amyloid degeneration in a patient before and after she underwent superficial keratectomy for Salzmann nodular degeneration. polymorphic amyloid degeneration in a patient before surgery

images.alt: polymorphic amyloid degeneration in a patient before surgery
Red Eye - polymorphic amyloid degeneration in a patient before surgery
polymorphic amyloid degeneration in a patient after she underwent superficial keratectomy
Zoomed in polymorphic amyloid degeneration in a patient after she underwent superficial keratectomy

CORNEA.title: Avellino Dystrophy
CORNEA.contributor: Caroline W. Wilson, MD and Mark A. Greiner, MD
CORNEA.description: This 23-year-old female patient has granular type II (Avellino) corneal dystrophy and recurrent erosions. She has a strong family history of this autosomal dominant corneal dystrophy. In both eyes, there are linear lattice deposits and granular deposits in the central and paracentral anterior stroma with clear intervening stroma between the deposits. The right eye (top) has undergone phototherapeutic keratectomy and exhibits diffuse subepithelial haze. Treatment for her recurrent erosions included ocular surface lubrication with preservative-free artificial tears, sodium chloride 5% ointment, and rigid gas-permable contact lenses. Avellino Dystrophy OD

CORNEA.title: Subconjunctival Hemorrhage
CORNEA.contributor: Angela Mahoney; Anthony T. Chung, MD; Audrey C. Ko, MD
CORNEA.description: A subconjunctival hemorrhage occurs due to ruptured blood vessels in the conjunctiva. The blood accumulates between the sclera and the conjunctiva and appears as a red spot on the white of the eye. The bleeding can be caused by trauma, hypertension, elevated venous pressure (e.g., Valsalva maneuver, coughing, vomiting), anticoagulant therapy, and acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis [1]. The most common risk factors in younger patients are trauma and contact lens usage [2]

CORNEA.title: Subepithelial corneal haze after herpes zoster virus (HZV) keratitis
CORNEA.description: Subepithelial, or anterior stromal, corneal haze may result after superficial corneal inflammation. It can be seen as a reflective region when illuminated with a broad slit beam, but is most easily visible when using the slit beam. These photographs show the appearance of a patient with anterior stromal haze after herpes zoster virus (HZV) keratitis. The depth of the opacification is visible in the slit beam. Corneal haze can be seen as a reflective region when illuminated with a broad slit beam.

images.alt: Corneal haze can be seen as a reflective region when illuminated with a broad slit beam
Corneal haze is most easily visible when using the slit beam seen using the slit beam
Corneal haze is most easily visible when using the slit beam seen using the slit beam - Zoomed

CORNEA.title: Applanation epitheliopathy
CORNEA.contributor: Jesse Vislisel, MD and Wallace L.M. Alward, MD
CORNEA.description: Applanation tonometry is the gold standard for intraocular pressure assessment. During this technique a circular Goldmann applanation tip contacts the surface of the cornea. Epithelial disruption may occur if care is not taken during applanation, leading to a circle of positive fluorescein staining as seen in this photograph.

CORNEA.title: Corneal arcus (arcus senilis)
CORNEA.description: Corneal arcus, also known as arcus senilis or gerontoxon, is a common degenerative change of the peripheral cornea in older adults, but may be a sign of hyperlipoproteinemia in individuals under 40 years of age. Arcus results from the deposition of lipids in the peripheral cornea, typically beginning superiorly and inferiorly and eventually encircling the entire corneal circumference as seen in this photograph. The patient in this photo also has an area of temporal iris atrophy laterally adjacent to a laser peripheral iridotomy (LPI).

CORNEA.title: Avellino Dystrophy
CORNEA.contributor: Caroline W. Wilson, MD and Mark A. Greiner, MD
CORNEA.description: This 23-year-old female patient has granular type II (Avellino) corneal dystrophy and recurrent erosions. She has a strong family history of this autosomal dominant corneal dystrophy. In both eyes, there are linear lattice deposits and granular deposits in the central and paracentral anterior stroma with clear intervening stroma between the deposits. The right eye (top) has undergone phototherapeutic keratectomy and exhibits diffuse subepithelial haze. Treatment for her recurrent erosions included ocular surface lubrication with preservative-free artificial tears, sodium chloride 5% ointment, and rigid gas-permable contact lenses. Avellino Dystrophy OD

CORNEA.title: Band Keratopathy
CORNEA.description: It is often idiopathic. BK usually begins as fine, yellow-white deposits in the periphery that may coalesce over time to form a horizontal band across the cornea. Figure 1. Calcific band keratopathy secondary to hyperparathyroidism Figure 1-A

CORNEA.title: Subconjunctival Hemorrhage
CORNEA.contributor: Angela Mahoney; Anthony T. Chung, MD; Audrey C. Ko, MD
CORNEA.description: A subconjunctival hemorrhage occurs due to ruptured blood vessels in the conjunctiva. The blood accumulates between the sclera and the conjunctiva and appears as a red spot on the white of the eye. The bleeding can be caused by trauma, hypertension, elevated venous pressure (e.g., Valsalva maneuver, coughing, vomiting), anticoagulant therapy, and acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis [1]. The most common risk factors in younger patients are trauma and contact lens usage [2]

CORNEA.title: Bitot Spot
CORNEA.contributor: Pavlina Kemp, MD & Mark Greiner, MD

images.alt: BK usually begins as fine, yellow-white deposits in the periphery that may coalesce over time to form a horizontal band across the cornea

CORNEA.title: Calcific band keratopathy with lucent holes
CORNEA.description: Calcific band keratopathy (BK) is a corneal degeneration that is characterized by deposition of calcium within the superficial cornea, mainly within Bowman's layer. BK usually begins as fine, yellow-white deposits in the periphery that may coalesce over time to form a horizontal band across the cornea. This photograph shows BK in a patient with HLA-B27-associated uveitis. The "Swiss cheese" appearance derives from lucent "holes" in the calcific pattern due to corneal nerve penetration through Bowman's layer.

images.alt: BK usually begins as fine, yellow-white deposits in the periphery that may coalesce over time to form a horizontal band across the cornea. This photograph shows BK in a patient with HLA-B27-associated uveitis. The "Swiss cheese" appearance derives from lucent "holes" in the calcific pattern due to corneal nerve penetration through Bowman's layer

CORNEA.title: Calcific band keratopathy associated with juvenile idiopathic arthritis
CORNEA.description: Calcific band keratopathy (BK) is a corneal degeneration that is characterized by deposition of calcium within the superficial cornea, mainly within Bowman's layer. BK usually begins as fine, yellow-white deposits in the periphery that may coalesce over time to form a horizontal band across the cornea. These photographs show early BK in a patient with uveitis associated with juvenile idiopathic arthritis. The accompanying iron line denotes the chronicity of these corneal changes.

images.alt: Band keratopathy juvenile idiopathic arthritis -slit lamp

CORNEA.title: Calcific band keratopathy, late:
CORNEA.description: This photograph shows late BK with a chalky, white consistency.

images.alt: BK usually begins as fine, yellow-white deposits in the periphery that may coalesce over time to form a horizontal band across the cornea

CORNEA.title: Blepharitis
CORNEA.description: Blepharitis is inflammation of the eyelid margins, often associated with staphylococcal colonization or seborrheic dermatitis. Findings include scaling and crusting around eyelashes on the anterior lid margin, as seen in this photograph, with resulting ocular surface irritation and inflammation.

CORNEA.title: Angioid Blepharokeratoconjunctivitis of childhood
CORNEA.description: Blepharokeratoconjunctivitis of childhood is characterized by blepharitis with recurrent episodes of conjunctivitis and keratopathy, including punctate erosions, phlyctenules, marginal keratitis, and ulceration. Treatment may include warm compresses, lid scrubs, topical antibiotics, topical corticosteroids, and systemic antibiotics. The disease rarely progresses after age 8.This 7-year-old female has a history of recurrent styes, corneal phlyctenules, and filamentary keratitis, as demonstrated in these photos.

images.alt: corneal phlyctenules, and filamentary keratitis - close-up

CORNEA.title: Candida growth within DSAEK interface
CORNEA.description: Performing routine corneal cultures on the donor corneal rim at the time of keratoplasty is controversial among corneal surgeons. This patient underwent Descemet stripping automated endothelial keratoplasty (DSAEK) for Fuchs corneal endothelial dystrophy and cultures on the donor rim grew Candida albicans. Three months after the procedure, the patient was noted to have Candida growth within the interface between the graft and host tissue despite prophylactic anti-fungal therapy. The fungus was resistant to further medical therapy and recurred after repeat DSAEK and intracameral voriconazole. He subsequently required a penetrating keratoplasty (PKP) which successfully eradicated the infection.

images.alt: Fungus - DSAEK interface Slit lamp Different Angle

CORNEA.title: Candida infection of a Boston Type I Keratoprosthesis (KPro)
CORNEA.photographer: Brice Critser, CRA (fig 1); Stefani Karakas, CRA(fig. 2)
CORNEA.description: The Boston Type I Keratoprosthesis is a prosthetic corneal replacement used to restore vision in individuals with severe corneal disease and contraindications to traditional keratoplasty techniques. Like other artificial implants in the body, the KPro may be a nidus for infection. Fungal infections may occur around the device stem and appear milky-white, as seen in these photographs. Also shown is a photograph prior to the infection for comparison (figure 1). Figure 1: Boston Type I Keratoprosthesis

CORNEA.title: Cogan's syndrome
CORNEA.description: Cogan's syndrome is a rare, idiopathic, chronic inflammatory disorder characterized vestibuloauditory dysfunction and interstitial keratitis. Some evidence suggests an autoimmune mechanism, but the true etiology unknown. The classic ophthalmic feature is interstitial keratitis causing patchy, granular corneal stromal infiltrates that may result in anterior stromal and subepithelial scarring. Patients may have other signs of ocular inflammation including uveitis, conjunctivitis, episcleritis, scleritis or retinal vasculitis. The inner ear disease associated with Cogan's syndrome can manifest as vertigo, ataxia, tinnitus or hearing loss. Anti-inflammatory and/or immunosuppressive therapy are the treatments based on the clinical features

CORNEA.title: Complex choristoma of the conjunctiva
CORNEA.description: Choristomas are benign, congenital proliferations of normal tissue that is not typically found at the site of the mass. Conjunctival examples include limbal dermoids, lipodermoids, ectopic lacrimal glands, and osseus choristomas. Complex choristomas contain features of multiple types of choristomas. They often cannot be distinguished from dermoids or lipodermoids clinically. This young girl presented with a temporal epibulbar mass that slowly enlarged since birth. Histology of the lesion showed features of both lipodermoid and osseous choristoma (bone formation)

CORNEA.title: Conductive keratoplasty (CK) scars
CORNEA.description: Conductive keratoplasty (CK) is a refractive procedure in which regions of the cornea are heated to cause collagen shrinkage and change the corneal shape to correct mild to moderate hyperopia. This patient has multiple circular anterior stromal scars as evidence of his past conductive keratoplasty. Some of these scars are visible in these wide and narrow slit beam photographs.

CORNEA.title: Confocal microscopy in fungal keratitis
CORNEA.contributor: Kurt Chamberlain MS3, Justin Risma MD
CORNEA.description: This patient had a history of fungal keratitis secondary to contact lens wear. She was treated successfully with topical anti-fungal therapy, but developed a dense corneal scar. She underwent penetrating keratoplasty, but a few months after surgery she presented with a recurrent corneal infiltrate and a hypopyon. The diagnosis of recurrent fungal keratitis was made in part with the use of in vivo confocal microscopy

images.alt: fungal keratitis secondary to contact lens wear
confocal microscopy of fungal structures in the eye

CORNEA.title: Congenital aniridia
CORNEA.photographer: Brice Critser, CRA, Cindy Montague, CRA
CORNEA.description: Congenital aniridia is a hereditary disease most commonly with autosomal dominant inheritance. These slit lamp photographs of a 17-year-old with aniridia show corneal pannus, subepithelial haze, and iris hypoplasia. There is fluorescein uptake of the pannus due to leaky intracellular junctions. The patient also has small anterior polar cataracts. The macular OCT shows absence of the normal foveal depression, consistent with foveal hypoplasia Slit lamp photographs - corneal pannus

images.alt: fluorescein uptake of the pannus due
fluorescein uptake of the pannus due
The patient had small anterior polar cataracts
The patient had small anterior polar cataracts

CORNEA.title: Congenital aniridia(2)
CORNEA.description: Congenital aniridia is a hereditary disease most commonly with autosomal dominant inheritance. These slit lamp photographs show iris hypoplasia and corneal scarring in a patient with congenital aniridia. This patient underwent cataract surgery and has 3-piece posterior chamber intraocular lenses in both eyes which are easily visible with retroillumination. This patient with congenital aniridia has 3-piece posterior chamber intraocular lenses in both eyes

images.alt: congenital aniridia has 3-piece posterior chamber intraocular lenses
congenital aniridia has 3-piece posterior chamber intraocular lenses

CORNEA.title: Conjunctival epithelial inclusion cyst
CORNEA.description: Epithelial inclusion cysts of the conjunctiva may be congenital or acquired. Acquired cysts form when epithelial cells are displaced into the substantia propria where they proliferate to form a cystic cavity filled with clear fluid. The cysts are usually asymptomatic and can typically be observed only. Below are photographs of three different appearances of conjunctival epithelial inclusion cysts in three different patients. Only the largest of the three was symptomatic, requiring surgical resection. Patient 1

images.alt: Epithelial inclusion cysts zoom - slit lamp
Epithelial inclusion cysts zoom - slit lamp
Epithelial inclusion cysts zoom - slit lamp

CORNEA.title: Conjunctival lymphoid hyperplasia
CORNEA.description: Conjunctival lymphoid hyperplasia is a benign lymphoid proliferation which appears as a smooth, mobile, salmon-colored, fleshy mass. Suspicious masses must be biopsied as they cannot be differentiated from conjunctival lymphoma clinically. Caption

CORNEA.title: Conjunctival varix
CORNEA.description: Conjunctival varices are abnormally dilated venous channels within the conjunctiva. They are typically freely mobile relative to the sclera. These venous malformations are usually asymptomatic and do not require any specific treatment. They can be excised for cosmetic reasons, but one should be aware that they may have orbital extensions.

images.alt: dilated venous channels within the conjunctiv

CORNEA.title: Conjunctival lymphoma
CORNEA.description: Conjunctival lymphoma classically appears as a smooth, mobile, salmon-colored, fleshy mass. The lesions are most commonly unilateral. They cannot be differentiated from benign lymphoid hyperplasia based on clinical appearance alone, and thus require biopsy. This lesion was biopsied and found to be an extranodal marginal zone (MALT) B-cell lymphoma.

CORNEA.title: Conjunctival papilloma
CORNEA.description: Conjunctival papillomas located in the inferior fornix are often pedunculated with a multilobulated appearance. These benign neoplasms are initiated after infection by the human papillomavirus (HPV).

images.alt: Conjunctival papillomas located in the inferior fornixt

CORNEA.title: Corneal abrasion
CORNEA.description: This image shows a corneal epithelial defect, or corneal abrasion, after the application of fluorescein dye. The staining pattern is more visible under cobalt blue light.

CORNEA.title: Corneal Hydrops
CORNEA.description: Corneal hydrops is the acute onset of corneal edema due to a break in Descemet membrane. This condition may be seen in individuals with advanced keratoconus or other forms of corneal ectasia. Recovery may take weeks to months with medical therapy, but may be accelerated by the placement of air or gas into the anterior chamber to slow the influx of aqueous into the cornea. Scarring, and sometimes corneal flattening, will occur after resolution of the episode. Entry #1 Entry #1 Contributor: Matthew Meyer, MD Photographer: Sarah Skiles February 12, 2024 Oblique slit-lamp view of acute corneal hydrops highlighting significant apical corneal edema with corresponding anterior slit-lamp view and corneal tomography. Fig 1
